reviewText: Too little is known about those Germans who did resist the Nazis from 1933 to 1945, especially since many of us had been taught during childhood that all the German people supported Hitler when he was in power. This documentary does a good job of dispelling that myth.People who have never lived under a dictatorship as ruthlessly efficient as the Nazis can never know the kind of courage it would take to stand-up to such a regime, despite the infinitesimal chance that their efforts would result in the fall of the Nazis or death of Hitler. Given that the Nazis killed or imprisoned many of their opponents shortly after their takeover and the Gestapo was constantly on the lookout for dissenters afterwards, resistance to the Nazis involved such people risking everything they had, including their lives and the lives of their families.Due to the filmValkyrie, most people are aware of the attempted assassination on July 20, 1944 and the filmSwing Kidsbrought attention to the early resistance to the Nazis by young people active in Germany's 1930s jazz subculture. But these films were made mostly by casting Hollywood stars to lure people into theaters and featuring soundtracks to entertain us with music.The Restless Conscienceis a documentary and offered nothing more than the information most people did not possess before seeing it. While it may seem to be dry in its delivery, resembling a television report more than anything else, it shows us some of the bravest of the German people: those who dared resist the Nazis when most Germans either could not - or would not - do so.I wish that the 2004 filmEdelweiss Pirates (Original Germain Version With English Subtitles)was also available for Instant download, but you can buy the DVD.
summary: Martyrs in the War Against Hitler
Title: N/A

reviewText: Why did the governments of so many countries choose not to listen? A simple answer is that they choose the easy 'pathway' to avoid a war. There is enough documentation to establish the validity of German concerns that one might wonder, 'What if?' This documentary answers many questions that have been asked about 'how did this happen?' The original footage and photos add dimension to the interviews. The interviews that are in German offer subtitles with reasonably accurate translations. The pace is slow but it is still interesting. Take the time to understand the depth of intrigue and the different personalities. Civil servants, those in the military, the legal and medical community, religious leaders, student organizations, and so many others were involved. Recommended for those who may not understand that there were those who did oppose Nazism and chose to take action. A documentary that is a reminder that genocide should be stopped before it begins and of the consequences that can follow.

reviewText: If I am put in a similar situation, how's my conscience? Will I respond in like manner? Things are going on in our nation today that make me think we are headed for a test of our conscience. I pray that I have not only the right conscience, but the guts, the courage to stand up for what is right. Thank you to all the folks at Amazon.com who made this DVD available. Jana

reviewText: This documentary explores a much under-examined element of Hitler'sGermany. German citizens, some of high army rank or social status, whorisked everything, and usually forfeited their lives to try to stopHitler.These people had nothing to gain, and everything to lose. They could ofgone along quietly, and kept their lives and their life styles, Butinstead they trade it all to fight for an ideal.The film-making itself can be a bit dry; lots of talking heads, WW IIfootage and stills, and fairly dispassionate sounding narrators tellingus the facts. But the stories themselves are heartbreaking - especiallythe desperate attempts to warn the outside world what was coming,getting only mistrust and indifference in response.Also remarkable are the bits of actual footage from the show trials theNazi's gave these men before killing them. Their quiet, brave dignityin the face of death is deeply powerful.

reviewText: This is a documentary about the Germans who were in the resistance opposing Hitler and the Socialist government. In this documentary you will learn first hand from the people who were there what took place and why in the end plots were formed to assassinate Hitler; which caused those in the resistance to have a "restless conscience." Learn from their experiences and the necessity to stand up for what is morally right before it becomes too late.
summary: A Lesson From The Past For All Today

reviewText: When students ask their teachers, "Why did the Germans allow Hitler to seize power? Why didn't they stop him from killing the Jews?" they should tell the stories of these martyrs who lived with such strong conviction that they offered up their lives for the sake of truth and freedom. The interviews with surviving family and friends are priceless, but the pace of the film is slowed as they recount their loved one's saga. Anyone interested in history or politics will find this film fascinating.

reviewText: This film should be required viewing in all history classes.  Hava Beller does an outstanding job of walking us through the efforts to assassinate Hitler.  Progressive forces in the military - many decorated Generals with family pedigrees for generations - were on board with the attempts.  They even approached England and France for assistance - which, had it come to light, would have meant certain death.  They were rebuffed by both.  Of course, all of the progressive military officers who figured in these plots were executed after the failed July 20th attempt, and by horrific means.  But the film really succeeds in getting the viewer to ask why England and France were unwilling to offer assistance.  The question is only asked, not answered.  One suspects that it might have been because they wanted triumph over cooperation.  The film makes the salient point that if the attempts had succeeded, millions of lives could have been spared.  It is far too easy to demonize, but what of those who could have ended the fascist nightmare much earlier?
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Restless Conscience"  is an Academy Award nominee that explores the motivating principles and activities of the anti-Nazi resistance inside Germany from 1933 to 1945.  The film is a moving portrayal of individual destinies, focusing on the moral and political evolution of people whose conscience was at odds with an overpowering national consensus.  Filmmaker Hava Kohav Beller points out that in 1944, at least 170 German citizens were convicted as participants in a plot to assassinate Adolf Hitler.  This was the last of more than 20 attempts to overthrow the Nazi regime.  "The Restless Conscience" highlights the tension between individual responsibility to a personal ethical code and fear of a tyrannical political system.  Bonus extras include an interview with the filmmaker.
Title: N/A

reviewText: When this film came out in 1992, much less had been documented and published about the German resistance to Hitler and the Nazis than is now known. It was, therefore, an important film in its time. And although the film now therefore feels somewhat dated, some of the interviews (filmed in the 1980s) are invaluable. The filmmaker, Hava Kohav Beller, interviewed 30 relatives and friends of resisters, and 5 actual resisters. An interview with a former German army officer, Axel von dem Bussche, was especially riveting for his description of an SS extermination squad in the Ukraine, and how this changed him.
Title: N/A
